ygData.subject: Re: Test of Truth info
ygData.msgSnippet: ... there s ... The titled used depends on the situation. In military situations (on duty, at a military function, etc...) the Military title (Captain,
ygData.messageBody:
--- Shawn Alley <ShawnA@...> wrote:
>> And finally (those crazy British nobles), if
there's
>> a military title too; it goes before them all;
>> though it would be a rare occasion to use all three
>> titles when refering to the individual:
>> Captain Sir Hamish Alexander
>> Captain Earl Sir Hamish Alexander
>> Captain Dame Honor Harrington
>> Captain Lady Dame Honor Harrington

> So I am guessing you choose the "highest" title when
> addressing someone with three titles? dunno

The titled used depends on the situation.

In military situations (on duty, at a military
function, etc...) the Military title (Captain,
Commander, etc...) would be used.

In purely civilian situations (having dinner,
socializing with nobility, etc...) the Nobility title
(Lord, Lady, Duke, Duchess, etc...) would be used.

The Knight title would be the least used, but would
often be combined with the nobility title.

Oddities!

===
:D
Dave's World
-No matter where you go, there you are-
"People will believe a lie either because they want to
believe it's true, or because they fear it is." Wizard's
First Rule, Sword of Truth, Terry Goodkind
